To realize this project, the agent persuades the black slaves to fight for their liberation from slavery. |- | ''[[Caribbean Gold]]'' || 1952 || |- | ''[[Captain Blood (1935 film)|Captain Blood]]'' || 1935 || An enslaved Irish doctor becomes a pirate. |- | ''[[Cloud Atlas (film)|Cloud Atlas]]'' |2012 |Plotlines involving escapes from historical and futuristic forms of slavery |- | ''[[C.S.A.: The Confederate States of America]]'' || 2004 || A faux British documentary of today reviewing American history, operating under the counter-historical premise that the [[Confederate States of America]] won the [[American Civil War]], annexed all of the United States in the process, and thereby preserved and expanded slavery throughout the nation. |- | ''[[Django Unchained]]'' || 2012 || In the [[American South]] in 1858, a slave is purchased by a [[Germany|German]] [[dentist]] turned [[bounty hunter]], and then agrees to help him track down a small group of dangerous outlaws in exchange for his freedom and the rescuing of his wife from a cruel plantation owner. |- | ''[[Drum (1976 film)|Drum]]'' || 1976 || The film, a sequel to ''[[Mandingo (film)|Mandingo]]'', features a black slave who falls in love with a plantation owner's daughter. When the owner threatens castration, the slave plans a revolt.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[El Cimarron (film)|El Cimarron]]'' || 2007 || Based on the life of [[Marcos Xiorro]] who conspired and planned a [[slave revolt]] in [[Puerto Rico]] in 1821. |- | ''[[Enslavement: The True Story of Fanny Kemble]]'' || 2000 || The film depicts the story of British actress and abolitionist [[Fanny Kemble]], who becomes horrified by [[Treatment of slaves in the United States|the treatment of her husband's enslaved people]]. Fanny later publishes her journals and their [[Slave narrative|first-hand accounts]] of slavery, helping influence the British government's decision to withhold support of the [[Confederate States of America|Confederacy]] during the [[American Civil War]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20000423&slug=4016942 |title='Enslavement' takes some liberties with abolitionist Fanny Kemble's tale |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |publisher=[[The Seattle Times Company]] |first=Misha|last=Berson |date=April 23, 2000 |accessdate=October 7, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.philly.com/2000-04-21/news/25588871_1_pierce-butler-story-of-fanny-kemble-masterpiece-theatre |title=Hysterical drama of historical figure |work=[[Los Angeles Daily News]] |publisher=[[MediaNews Group]] |first=David |last=Kronke |date=April 21, 2000 |accessdate=October 7, 2013}}</ref> |- | ''[[Fortunes of Captain Blood]]'' || 1950 || |- | ''[[The Foxes of Harrow]]'' || 1947 || Covering approximately the years 1827–1837, an illegitimate son of an Irish aristocratic family comes to America. He is a gambler and scoundrel who acquires a large plantation with many slaves, and builds an empire in antebellum [[New Orleans]]. The movie was the first based upon a book written by an African-American writer.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Free State of Jones (film)|Free State of Jones]]'' || 2016 || Disenchanted [[Confederate States Army|confederate]] soldiers rally with runaway slaves to establish an abolitionist colony in Mississippi, led by [[Newton Knight]], who fathers a child with a black woman. That story is framed by the one of his great-grandsons, who is prosecuted in 1948 for attempting to marry a white woman while possibly being of mixed descent. |- | ''[[Frederick Douglass and the White Negro]]'' || 2008 || A documentary telling the story of ex-slave, [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]], writer and politician [[Frederick Douglass]] and his escape to Ireland from America in the 1840s. |- | ''[[Freedom (2014 film)|Freedom]]'' || 2014 || In the United States in the 1850s, a black man attempts to free his family from a tobacco plantation.<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[Ganga Zumba (film)|Ganga Zumba]]'' || 1963 || Not released until 1972 because of a military coup in Brazil, the film highlights [[Ganga Zumba]], a 17th-century slave revolutionary. |- | ''[[Gladiator (2000 film)|Gladiator]]'' || 2000 || A Roman general in the 2nd century A.D. is turned into a slave who must fight for his life, and his country, as a [[gladiator]]. |- | ''[[Glory (1989 film)|Glory]]'' || 1989 || During the [[American Civil War]], an escaped slave joins an all-black fighting unit of the [[Union Army]].<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Goodbye Uncle Tom]]'' || 1971 || ''Addio Zio Tom'' is a pseudo-documentary in which the filmmakers go back in time and visit antebellum America, using period documents to examine, in graphic detail, the racist ideology and degrading conditions faced by Africans under slavery.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'' || 1939 || The film features a slave nursemaid as a prominent supporting character. Actress [[Hattie McDaniel]] made history by becoming the first [[African American]] woman to win an [[Academy Award]] for her performance ([[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]]).<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[A House Divided: Denmark Vesey's Rebellion]]'' ||1982|| A 1982 television film about Denmark Vesey, a literate skilled carpenter and former slave who planned a slave rebellion in 1822 in Charleston, South Carolina. |- | ''[[I Am Slave]]'' || 2010 || A U.K. television story of one woman's fight for freedom from modern-day slavery, based on the experience of [[Mende Nazer]], a British author, human rights activist, and a former [[Slavery in Sudan|slave in Sudan]]. |- | ''[[Ill Gotten Gains]]'' || 1997 || Independent film about the [[Atlantic slave trade]] |- | ''[[Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom]]'' || 1984 || In the film, [[child slavery|enslaved children]] are forced to mine for Sankara stones. |- | ''[[Jefferson in Paris]]'' || 1995 || The film shows the relationship between [[Thomas Jefferson]], who was one of the Founding Fathers of the United States and a slave owner, and [[Sally Hemings]], a biracial slave.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Joseph (film)|Joseph]]'' || 1995 || The biblical story of [[Joseph (son of Jacob)|Joseph]] and his brothers. Joseph is an Egyptian slave who earns a reputation as an interpreter of dreams. |- | ''[[Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat (film)|Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat]] || 1999 || [[Joseph (son of Jacob)|Joseph's]] biblical story portrayed in a musical by [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]], starred [[Donny Osmond]] as Joseph. |- | ''[[Joseph: King of Dreams]]'' || 2000 || The Biblical story of Joseph portrayed in an animated musical. |- | ''{{sortname|The|Journey of August King}}'' || 1995|| A widowed farmer reluctantly provides safe passage to a run-away slave as he returns home from an annual trip to purchase provisions and supplies, starring [[Jason Patric]] as August King and [[Thandie Newton]] as Annalees. |- | ''{{sortname|The|Keeping Room}}'' || 2014 || The film takes place during the [[American Civil War]]. Three women in the South have to protect their home against soldiers of the [[Union Army]].<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[The Last Supper (1976 film)|The Last Supper]]'' || 1976 || A [[plantation]] owner during [[Spanish colonization of the Americas|Spanish colonial]] times recreates the last supper using slaves, in order to teach them about [[Christianity]]. |- | ''{{sortname|The|Legend of Nigger Charley}}'' || 1972 || The [[blaxploitation]] film takes place in America in the [[Antebellum era|Antebellum South]]. It follows three slaves seeking their freedom. |- | ''[[The Legend of Tarzan (film)|The Legend of Tarzan]]''|| 2016 || [[George Washington Williams]] convinces [[Tarzan]] (John Clayton III, the Earl of Greystoke) to travel back to Africa to investigate claims of an ongoing slave trade. |- | ''[[Lincoln (2012 film)|Lincoln]]'' || 2012 || Near the end of the [[American Civil War]], President [[Abraham Lincoln]] pushes to abolish slavery in the U.S. by urging Congress to pass the [[Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]].<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[The Littlest Rebel]]'' || 1935 || |- | ''[[Manderlay]]'' || 2005 || Set in the early 1930s, the film tells the story of Grace, an idealist who attempts to oust the owners of a plantation in Alabama and free the slaves living there. |- | ''[[Mandingo (film)|Mandingo]]'' || 1975 || A slave owner insists that his son, who is sleeping with the slaves, marry a white woman and father him a son. He marries, and trains a Mandingo slave to be a bare-knuckle fighter. |- | ''[[Motherland (2010 film)|Motherland]]'' || 2010 || Documentary sequel to ''[[500 Years Later]]'', the film gives an overview of the history of the African continent and its people from Ancient Egypt to the present. |- |''[[Nat Turner: A Troublesome Property]]'' || 2003 || Documentary film about Nat Turner |- | ''[[North and South (TV miniseries)|North and South]]'' || 1985–1994 || A three-part TV miniseries outlining the period leading to and during the American civil war, and the post-war [[Reconstruction era of the United States|Reconstruction]]. |- | ''{{sortname|The|North Star|dab=film}}'' || 2013 || The film is based on "the true story of Big Ben Jones, a slave who escaped from a Southern plantation in 1848 and is helped by local [[Quakers]]".<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[Passage du milieu]]'' || 1999 || [[Docudrama]] about a [[Atlantic slave trade|trans-Atlantic]] [[slave ship]] voyage of black slaves from the West Coast of Africa to the Caribbean, a part of the [[triangular slave trade]] route called the [[Middle Passage]]. |- | ''[[Paradesi (2013 film)|Paradesi]]'' || 2013 || A Tamil language movie that is based on true events that took place in a tea plantation during the 1930s. |- | ''[[Prince Among Slaves (film)|Prince Among Slaves]]'' || 2006 || A [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] historical documentary about the life of [[Abdulrahman Ibrahim Ibn Sori]], a prince from West Africa who was made a slave in the United States and freed 40 years later on orders of the American president, [[John Quincy Adams]]. |- | ''[[The Prince of Egypt]]'' || 1998 || Former Prince [[Moses]] frees the Hebrew slaves from the [[Pharaoh]] of [[Egypt]]. |- | ''[[Quilombo (film)|Quilombo]]'' || 1984 || Account of [[Quilombo dos Palmares]], a 17th-century Brazilian community of escaped slaves. Features its one-time leader, [[Zumbi]]. |- | ''[[Raiders of the Seven Seas]]'' || 1953 || |- |''[[The Retrieval]]'' |2013 |During the Civil War, a young free boy is sent north by his bounty hunter gang to retrieve a wanted fugitive slave. |- | ''[[Return of the Jedi]]'' || 1983 || (Arguably the captivity of Princess Leia in Jabba the Hutt's court makes the institution a side-theme.) |- | ''[[Roots (1977 miniseries)|Roots]]'' || 1977 || An acclaimed eight-episode TV mini-series based on [[Alex Haley]]'s biography about his family moving from slavery to liberation.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Roots (2016 miniseries)|Roots]]'' || 2016 || A four-episode remake of the 1977 miniseries. |- | ''[[Roots: The Gift]] || 1988 || A film portraying events occurring between the second and third episodes of the first miniseries. |- | ''[[Sankofa (film)|Sankofa]]'' || 1993 || In the supernatural film, a black American model travels to [[Ghana]] and is transported back in time by a local mystic. The model finds herself a slave in the past.<ref name="root" /> |- | ''[[Santa Fe Trail (film)|Santa Fe Trail]]'' || 1940 || Western centered around abolitionist [[John Brown (abolitionist)|John Brown]], his attacks on slavery as a prelude to the Civil War, and the attempt to find his hideout and stop his violent campaign. |- | ''[[Savannah (film)|Savannah]]'' || 2013 || Loosely based on the book ''Ducks, Dogs and Friends'', the film is about a white hunter who befriends a freed slave.<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[Seven Angry Men]]'' || 1955 || Follows John Brown's campaign to end slavery and his raid on [[John Brown's raid on Harpers Ferry|Harper's Ferry]]. |- | ''[[The Slave Hunters]]'' || 2010 || Slave hunter goes after an escaped General-turned-slave in this South Korean 24-episode television series. |- | ''[[Slaves (film)|Slaves]]'' || 1969 || Follows the life of two slaves in the American South of the 1850s. |- | ''[[Solomon Northup's Odyssey]]'' || 1984 || The film is based on the true story of [[Solomon Northup]], a free black man who was kidnapped in [[Washington, DC]] in 1841 and sold into slavery.<ref name="corry" /> |- | ''[[Spartacus (film)|Spartacus]] || [[Spartacus (film)|1960]] & [[Spartacus (miniseries)|2004]] || In [[Spartacus]], a film that stays close to the historical record,<ref>Davis, ''Slaves on Screen: Film and Historical Vision'' (2002) ch 3</ref> a [[Thracian]] enslaved as a gladiator by the [[Roman Republic]] leads a [[Third Servile War|slave revolt]] that engulfs much of the Italian peninsula. |- | ''[[Tamango]] || 1958 || A slave ship crosses the Atlantic, and the slaves rebel. A film by [[Hollywood Blacklist|Hollywood blacklisted]] director [[John Berry (film director)|John Berry]] starring [[Dorothy Dandridge]] and [[Curd Jürgens]]. |- | ''[[The Ten Commandments (1956 film)|The Ten Commandments]]'' || [[The Ten Commandments (1923 film)|1923]] & [[The Ten Commandments (1956 film)|1956]] || [[Bible|Biblical]] story of the life of [[Moses]], an adopted [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] prince who becomes the deliverer of his real brethren, the enslaved [[Israelites|Hebrews]]. |- | ''[[Tula: The Revolt]]'' || 2013 || In 1795 on [[Curaçao]], then a Dutch colony, a slave uprising takes place.<ref name="samuels" /> |- | ''[[The Viking (1928 film)|The Viking]] || 1928 || Lord Alwin is captured in a viking raid and taken to Norway as a slave.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0019532/|title=The Viking (1928)|website=IMDB}}</ref> |- | ''[[Unchained Memories]]'' || 2003 || An [[HBO]] documentary featuring the stories of former slaves interviewed during the 1930s as part of the [[Federal Writers' Project]]. It compiles slave narratives which are narrated by actors emulating the original conversation with the interviewer. |- | ''[[Film adaptations of Uncle Tom's Cabin|Uncle Tom's Cabin]]'' || 1903||Many film adaptations of [[Harriet Beecher Stowe|Harriet Beecher Stowe's]] novel have been made, nine from the silent era (including those of [[Uncle Tom's Cabin (1910 Thanhouser film)|1910]], [[Uncle Tom's Cabin (1918 film)|1918]], and [[Uncle Tom's Cabin (1927 film)|1927]]), and a [[Uncle Tom's Cabin (1965 film)|German version]] in 1965. |- | ''[[A Woman Called Moses]]'' || 1978 || A film about the life and career of the [[African American]] abolitionist and slave escape leader, [[Harriet Tubman]]. |- | ''[[A Woman Captured]]'' || 2017 || A documentary about a woman who is kept as domestic slave in Europe. |- | ''[[Zama (2017 film)|Zama]]'' || 2017 || The film is set in the late 18th century in a remote South American colony under the [[Spanish Empire]], and portrays the period's "naturalness of slavery".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lavoz.com.ar/numero-cero/el-arte-de-la-espera-esta-semana-se-estrena-zama-de-lucrecia-martel|title=El arte de la espera: esta semana se estrena "Zama", de Lucrecia Martel|date=September 24, 2017|language=Spanish|work=[[La Voz del Interior]]|accessdate=November 19, 2017|last=Koza|first=Roger}}</ref> |}

'''Madame E. Toussaint Welcome''', born '''Jennie Louise Van Der Zee''' (January 10, 1885 - 1956) was an [[African Americans|African-American]] visual artist associated with the [[Harlem Renaissance]]s. Van Der Zee who referred to herself as The Foremost Female artist of the Race,<ref name="Olin">{{cite book|title=Touching photographs|date=2012|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0226626468|location=Chicago|pages=101–102|last1=Olin|first1=Margaret}}</ref> is best recognized as being among the first few African-American Women Filmmaker from the silent film industry.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wfpp.cdrs.columbia.edu/essay/african-american-women-in-the-silent-film-industry/|title=African-American Women in the Silent Film Industry|website=Women Film Pioneers Project|last1=Morgan|first1=Kyan|last2=Dixon|first2=Kyna|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> She and her Husband Ernest Toussaint Welcome were also known as the husband-and-wife team of their time. Working closely together, they establish their own art school, photographic studio and film organization, from those they produced films and paintings that recognized the African-American soldiers of [[World War I|World War l]]. The Film; a twelve part documentary was titled; Doing the Bit in the.
== Early life == Van Der Zee was born in [[Lenox, Massachusetts]] to John Van Der Zee and Susan Brister Van Der Zee. Before moving to Lenox, Massachusetts, her parents were maid and butler in New York to president [[Ulysses S. Grant]]. Van Der Zee attended Lenox High School and took private lessons in art and music in [[Pittsfield, Massachusetts]].<ref name=":0">{{cite book|last1=Moutoussamy-Ashe|first1=Jeanne|title=Viewfinders : black women photographers : y Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe.|date=1993|publisher=Writers & readers|location=New York [etc]|isbn=978-0863161599|pages=29, 30|edition=[New edition]}}</ref> Early in the 20th century, she moved to New York with her father and brothers; including the famous [[photographer]], [[James Van Der Zee]]. She married Ernest Toussaint Welcome, an inventor and [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]], on January 10, 1910 and they moved together in a brownstone in [[New York City]]<ref name=":0" /> where they established the Toussaint Conservatory of Art and Music, an art school and photographic studio.<ref name=":0" /> The first advertisement for the conservatory appeared in the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People|NAACP]] journal's first issue, ''[[The Crisis]]''.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.masshist.org/object-of-the-month/september-2014|title=Massachusetts Historical Society: We Are Doing Our Bit: A 1918 Liberty Loan Poster with an African American Theme|website=www.masshist.org|access-date=2016-11-30}}</ref> In this issue Van Der Zee published a full-page advertisement for her art school and photographic studio where she also referred to herself in print as The Foremost Female Artist of the Race.<ref name="Olin" /> Van Der Zee stood out during her time because she was the African-American owner of a business in [[Harlem]]; where there was many white resident, that focused on the black community<ref name=":0" />
The couple made films and pictures that recognized African-American contributions to War World I. Under the banner of the Toussaint Motion Picture Exchange, they created a film titled ''Doing Their Bit'' in 1916, "a twelve-part series shown in two-reel segments,"<ref name="Kahana">{{cite book|last1=Kahana|first1=Jonathan|title=The documentary film reader: history, theory, criticism|date=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York, NY|pages=577, 587}}</ref> that focused on African-American military participation in the war. Van Der Zee also owned the Toussaint Studio. With a continued effort to acknowledge African-American patriotism, Van Der Ze made ''Charge of the Colored Division: Somewhere in France,''<ref name=":1" /> under The Toussaint Pictorial Company. The painting shows an African American war hero with his bayonet in the chest of a German soldier. Between 1917 and 1918 The Toussaint Pictorial Company published ''A Pictorial History of the Negro in the Great War,'' a memorial book that featured her work; ''Charge of the Colored Division. A Pictorial History of the Negro in the Great War'' also included pictures from governmental sources and a few uncredited photo.<ref name="Olin" />
== Later life == Toussaint Pictorial Company published one million patriotic postcards of African-American or "race" soldiers. After the war ended, the War Savings Stamp Committee accepted Van Der Zee's painting ''Charge of the Colored Divisions'' for use as a poster. Van Der Zee and her husband copyrighted the work in August 1918. No physical copies of their work are known to exist. According to the Massachusetts Historical Society, Van Der Zee died in 1956.

{{about|the late 20th-century movement in literature|the mid-20th-century style of architecture|New Formalism (architecture)}} '''New Formalism''' is a late 20th- and early 21st-century movement in [[American poetry]] that has promoted a return to [[Meter (poetry)|metrical]] and [[rhyme]]d verse.
==Origins and intentions==
The term 'New Formalism' was first used in the article 'The Yuppie Poet' in the May [[1985 in poetry|1985]] issue of the [[Associated Writing Programs|AWP]] Newsletter,<ref>Thompson, Nigel S., 'Form and Function,' ''P. N. Review,'' 154; the [[Associated Writing Programs]] article was written by [[Ariel Dawson]]</ref> which was an attack on what was perceived as a movement returning to traditional poetic forms. Dawson's article accused the New Formalist poets not only of social conservatism, but also of [[yuppie]] [[consumerism]].<ref>[[Paul Lake (poet)|Lake, Paul]], [https://archive.is/20050307211258/http://www.edge-city.com/lake.htm 'Expansive Poetry in the New Millennium'], a talk delivered at the West Chester Poetry Conference on 10 June 1999.</ref>
New Formalism was a reaction against various perceived deficiencies in the practice of contemporary poets. In his [[1987 in poetry|1987]] [[essay]] "Notes on the New Formalism," [[Dana Gioia]] wrote: "the real issues presented by American poetry in the Eighties will become clearer: the debasement of poetic language; the prolixity of the lyric; the bankruptcy of the confessional mode; the inability to establish a meaningful aesthetic for new poetic narrative and the denial of a musical texture in the contemporary poem. The revival of traditional forms will be seen then as only one response to this troubling situation."<ref>''[[The Hudson Review]]'' (40, 3, 1987)</ref> For women formalists, the situation was complicated by gender; as [[Annie Finch]] wrote in 1994 in the Introduction to "A Formal Feeling Comes: Poems in Form by Contemporary Women", "Readers who have been following the discussion of the "New Formalism" over the last decade may not expect to find such a diversity of writers and themes in a book of formal poems; the poems collected here contradict the popular assumption that formal poetics correspond to reactionary politics and elitist aesthetics ... The passion for form unites these many and diverse poets."This is 'New Formalism'.
==Background==
Despite the formal innovations of [[Modernism]] as exemplified in the work of [[T. S. Eliot]] and [[Ezra Pound]], and the widespread appearance of [[free verse]] in the early decades of the 20th century, many poets chose to continue working predominantly in traditional forms, such as [[Robert Frost]] as well as those poets in America sometimes associated with the [[New Criticism]], including [[John Crowe Ransom]], [[Robert Penn Warren]] and [[Allen Tate]]. During the 1960s, with a surge of interest in [[Confessional poetry]], publication of formal poetry became increasingly unfashionable. The emergence of the [[Language poets]] in the 1970s was one reaction to the predominance of the informal confessional lyric. But language poetry was another step away from the traditions of metre and rhyme, and was seen by some {{Who|date=December 2010}} as widening the divide between poetry and its public.{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}}
==Early history==
An early sign of a revival of interest in traditional poetic forms was the publication of [[Lewis Turco]]'s ''The Book of Forms: A Handbook of Poetics'' in [[1968 in poetry|1968]].<ref>''The Book of Forms: A Handbook of Poetics'' E. P. Dutton & Company, New York, 1968. A few years later Turco published a college textbook which presented poetry from the writer's perspective and emphasized the use of formal elements, this was ''Poetry: An Introduction through Writing'', Reston Publishing Co, 1973. {{ISBN|0-87909-637-3}}</ref> In the early 1970s [[X. J. Kennedy]] started publishing the short-lived magazine ''Counter/Measures'' which was devoted to the use of traditional form in poetry. A few other editors around this time were sympathetic to formal poetry,<ref>Timothy Steele in an [http://instructional1.calstatela.edu/tsteele/TSpage2/WalzerInter.html interview] mentions both [[Don Stanford]] at ''[[The Southern Review]]'' and [[Tom Kirby-Smith]] at ''[[The Greensboro Review]].'' He also mentions [[Robert L. Barth]]'s press and his series of metrical chapbooks.</ref> but the mainstream was against rhyme and meter.
One of the first rumbles of the conflict that was to provide the impetus to create New Formalism as a specific movement, came with the publication in 1977 of an issue of the Mississippi Review called 'Freedom and Form: American Poets Respond'. The late 1970s saw the publication of a few collections by poets working in traditional forms, including Robert B. Shaw's ''Comforting the Wilderness,'' (1977), [[Charles Martin (poet)|Charles Martin]]'s ''Room for Error,'' (1978) and [[Timothy Steele]]'s ''Uncertainties and Rest'' (1979). In [[1980 in poetry|1980]] [[Mark Jarman]] and Robert McDowell started the small magazine ''[[The Reaper (magazine)|The Reaper]]'' to promote narrative and formal poetry. In [[1981 in poetry|1981]] [[Jane Greer (poet)|Jane Greer]] launched ''Plains Poetry Journal'', which published new work in traditional forms. In [[1984 in poetry|1984]] McDowell started Story Line Press which has since published some New Formalist poets. ''The Reaper'' ran for ten years. [[Frederick Feirstein]]'s ''Expansive Poetry'' ([[1989 in poetry|1989]]) gathered various essays on the New Formalism and the related movement [[New Narrative]], under the umbrella term '[[Expansive Poetry]]'.
From 1983 the onset of "neoformalism" was noted in the annual poetry roundups in the yearbooks of ''The Dictionary of Literary Biography'',<ref>'The Year in Poetry' was contributed by Lewis Turco from 1983 to 1986.</ref> and through the mid-1980s heated debates on the topic of formalism were carried on in several journals.<ref>for example, see ''[[Salmagundi (magazine)|Salmagundi]]'' 65 (1984) with [[Mary Kinzie]]'s piece "[[The Rhapsodic Fallacy]]," (pages 63 – 79) and various responses; [[Alan Shapiro]]'s piece "The New Formalism," in ''[[Critical Inquiry]]'' 14.1 (1987) pages 200 – 13; and [[David Wojahn]]'s "'Yes, But ...': Some Thoughts on the New Formalism," in [[Crazyhorse]] 32 (1987) pages 64 – 81.</ref> [[1986 in poetry|1986]] saw the publication of [[Vikram Seth]]'s ''[[The Golden Gate (Vikram Seth novel)|The Golden Gate: A Novel in Verse]]'' and the anthology ''Strong Measures: Contemporary American Poetry in Traditional Forms''.<ref>''Strong Measures: Contemporary American Poetry in Traditional Forms'' edited by Philip Dacey and David Jauss</ref>
In [[1990 in poetry|1990]] [[William Baer (poet)|William Baer]] started ''[[The Formalist]]'' and the first issue contained poems by, among others, [[Howard Nemerov]], [[Richard Wilbur]], and [[Donald Justice]].<ref>http://theformalist.evansville.edu/backissueorders.html</ref> The magazine ran twice a year for fifteen years, with the fall/winter 2004 issue being the last.<ref>http://theformalist.evansville.edu/current.htm</ref> ''The Formalist'' was succeeded by ''[[Measure (journal)|Measure: A Review of Formal Poetry]],'' which is published biannually by the [[University of Evansville]].
==Current activity==
Since 1995, [[West Chester University]] has held an annual [[West Chester University Poetry Conference|poetry conference]] with a special focus on formal poetry and New Formalism. Each year the [[Robert Fitzgerald Prosody Award]] is awarded as part of the conference.
By the end of the 20th century, poems in traditional forms were once again being published more widely, and the new formalist movement per se was winding down. Since then, the effects of new formalism have been observed in the broader domain of general poetry; a survey of successive editions of various general anthologies showed an increase in the number of [[villanelle]]s included in the post-mid-'80s editions.<ref>French, Amanda Lowry, [http://www4.ncsu.edu/~alfrench/Writing/DISSERTATION.pdf Refrain, Again: The Return of the Villanelle], a doctoral dissertation, August 2004, page 13. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060721070940/http://www4.ncsu.edu/~alfrench/Writing/DISSERTATION.pdf |date=July 21, 2006 }}</ref> The publication of books concerned with poetic form has also increased. [[Lewis Turco]]'s ''Book of Forms'' from 1968 was revised and reissued in 1986 under the title 'New Book of Forms. [[Alfred Corn]]'s ''The Poem's Heartbeat'', Mary Oliver's ''Rules of the Dance'', and Stephen Frye's ''The Ode Less Travelled'' are other examples of this trend. The widely used anthology ''An Exaltation of Forms: Contemporary Poets Celebrate the Diversity of Their Art'' (University of Michigan Press, 2002), edited by [[Annie Finch]] and Kathrine Varnes, defines formalist poetry as a form on a par with experimental, free verse, and even prose poetry.
In 2001 the American poet [[Leo Yankevich]] founded ''[[The New Formalist]]'', which published among others the poets [[Jared Carter]]<ref>[http://theformalist.org/archives/62 Five Poems] at ''The New Formalist''</ref> and [[Keith Holyoak]].<ref>[http://theformalist.org/archives/161 Four Poems] at ''The New Formalist''</ref>
Interest in the movement and in formal techniques continues, as the West Chester conference demonstrates, but the movement is not without its detractors. In the November/December 2003 issue of ''[[P. N. Review]]'', N. S. Thompson wrote: "While movements do need a certain amount of bombast to fuel interest, they have to be backed up by a certain artistic success. In hindsight, the movement seems to be less of a poetic revolution and more a marketing campaign."<ref>[[N. S. Thompson]], 'Form and Function,' ''P. N. Review,'' 154.</ref>
==New Formalist canon==
The 2004 West Chester Conference had a by-invitation-only critical seminar on 'Defining the Canon of New Formalism', in which the following anthologies were discussed:<ref>[[Steven Schneider|Schneider, Steven]], 'Defining the Canon of New Formalist Poetry', ''Poetry Matters: The Poetry Center Newsletter,'' West Chester University. Number 2. February 2005</ref> * ''Rebel Angels: 25 Poets of the New Formalism'' edited by [[Mark Jarman]] and [[David Mason (writer)|David Mason]], [[1996 in poetry|1996]]. * ''The Direction of Poetry: An Anthology of Rhymed and Metered Verse Written in the English Language since 1975,'' edited by [[Robert Richman]] * ''A Formal Feeling Comes: Poems in Form by Contemporary Women,'' edited by [[Annie Finch]], 1993
==See also== {{portal|poetry}} *''[[The New Formalist]]'', a literary journal *''[[Eratosphere]]'' and ''[[Poetcraft Circles Community]]'', online communities associated with formal poetry *''[[The Lyric (magazine)]]'', a journal devoted to formal poetry *''[[Mezzo Cammin]]'', a journal devoted to formal poetry by women specifically

The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to sculpture:

A '''[[sculpture]]''' – human-made [[Dimension#Spatial dimensions|three-dimensional]] [[art]] object.

Sculpture or '''sculpting''' – activity of creating sculptures.  A person who creates sculptures is called a ''[[sculptor]]''.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== What ''type'' of thing is sculpture? ==
Sculpture can be described as all of the following:

* [[Art]] – aesthetic expression for presentation or performance, and the work produced from this activity. The word "art" is therefore both a verb and a noun, as is the term "sculpture".
** [[Work of art]] – aesthetic physical item or artistic creation.
** One of [[the arts]] – as an art form, sculpture is an outlet of human expression, that is usually influenced by culture and which in turn helps to change culture. Sculpture is a physical manifestation of the internal human creative impulse.
*** A branch of the [[visual arts]] – visual arts is a class of art forms, including painting, sculpture, photography, architecture and others, that focus on the creation of works which are primarily visual in nature.
** [[Fine art]] – in Western European academic traditions, fine art is art developed primarily for aesthetics, distinguishing it from applied art that also has to serve some practical function. The word "fine" here does not so much denote the quality of the artwork in question, but the purity of the discipline according to traditional Western European canons.

[[File:TianguisDomingoRamos2015 019.JPG|thumb|300px|Small section with pottery on the main square of Uruapan]] The '''Palm Sunday Handcraft Market''' ([[Tianguis]] de Domingo de Ramos), held in [[Uruapan]], is the largest event in the Mexican state of [[Michoacán]] dedicated to the sale of the [[Michoacán handcrafts and folk art|state’s traditional handcrafts]] and is reputed to be the largest of its kind in Latin America. The event draws over 1,300 artisans who offer over a million pieces for sale, which represent all of the state’s major handcraft traditions. It also includes other events such as a handcraft competition, exhibition of indigenous dress, food and other traditions, concerts, dance and more. The event is centered on the very large main plaza of the city of [[Uruapan]], but extends over to adjoining streets and to other plazas in the city.
==The tianguis== [[File:TianguisDomingoRamos2015 038.JPG|thumb|La Calavera Catrina figures from Capula at the market]] The tianguis (open air market) runs during [[Holy Week in Mexico|Holy Week]], officially beginning on the day before [[Palm Sunday]] and runs until the day after Easter Sunday, with the most important day being Palm Sunday (Domingo de Ramos).<ref name=srangel>{{cite news |title= Se alista el Tianguis Artesanal del Domingo de Ramos en Uruapan |newspaper= Diario ABC |location=Michoacán |url= http://diarioabc.com.mx/mobil/noticia_completa.php?id_item=Nzc1OA== |accessdate=April 4, 2015 }}</ref><ref name=mexdes>{{cite web |title=Domingo de Ramos en Uruapan (Michoacán) |publisher=Mexico Desconocido magazine |location=Mexico City |url= http://www.mexicodesconocido.com.mx/domingo-de-ramos-en-uruapan-michoacan.html |accessdate=April 4, 2015 }}</ref> This is a major vacation period in Mexico, and the event draws visitors from Mexico and abroad.<ref name=visitmich>{{cite web |title= Domingo de Ramos |publisher= State of Michoacán |url= http://www.visitmichoacan.com.mx/ss2015/domingo-ramos.html |accessdate= April 4, 2015 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://archive.is/20150404231637/http://www.visitmichoacan.com.mx/ss2015/domingo-ramos.html |archivedate= April 4, 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref name=travis>{{cite book |author=Travis M. Whitehead |title= Artisans of Michoacán:By their hands |publisher= Otras Voces Publishing |location= Brownsville, TX |year=2013 |isbn= 978 0 9857377 0 2 |pages=1–5 }}</ref><ref name=inauguran>{{cite news |title= Inauguran el Tianguis Artesanal de Domingo de Ramos 2015 |newspaper=Quadratin |location=Morelia |date=March 28, 2015 |url= http://www.quadratin.com.mx/principal/Inauguran-el-Tianguis-Artesanal-de-Domingo-de-Ramos-2015/ |accessdate=April 4, 2015 }}</ref>
It is the largest handcrafts event in Michoacán, followed closely by the Día de Muertos Fair in [[Pátzcuaro]], and it is claimed to be the largest of its kind in Latin America.<ref name=visitmich/><ref name=travis/><ref name=gponce>{{cite news |author= Grecia Ponce |title= Arranca Tianguis Artesanal de Domingo de Ramos en Uruapan |newspaper=Cambio de Michoacán |location=Morelia |date=March 28, 2015 |url= http://www.cambiodemichoacan.com.mx/nota-249872 |accessdate=April 4, 2015 }}</ref> In 2015, the event drew over 1,300 artisans from all over the state, especially the Purépecha highland region, from towns such as [[Tzintzuntzan, Michoacán|Tzintzuntzan]], [[San José de Gracia, Michoacán|San José de Gracia]], Capula, Huáncito, Patamban, Santo Tomas, Cocucho and [[Paracho]].<ref name=srangel/><ref name=mexdes/><ref name=gponce/> It is the most important event for the four major indigenous communities of Michoacán ([[Mazahua people|Mazahua]], [[Nahua peoples|Nahua]], [[Otomi people|Otomi]] and [[Purépecha people|Purépecha]]).<ref name=srangel/><ref name=inauguran/> However, not all vendors are the artisans themselves, some are resellers.<ref name=piden>{{cite news |author= Grecia Ponce |title= Piden artesanos sacar a revendedores del Tianguis Artesanal del Domingo de Ramos de Uruapan |newspaper=Cambio de Michoacán |location=Morelia |date=March 29, 2015 |url= http://www.cambiodemichoacan.com.mx/nota-249902 |accessdate=April 4, 2015 }}</ref>
[[File:TianguisDomingoRamos2015 053.JPG|thumb|left|Section of the market selling maque and textiles]] The tianguis fills the large main plaza (Plaza de Martíres de Uruapan) of the city and overflows to adjoining streets and other plazas such as Morelos Plaza, Huatapera Plaza and the Garcia Ortiz alleyway next to the Casa de Cultura (cultural center). Related events occurs in these areas as well as the Plaza de la Ranita, the Casa de Cultura, and the entrance to the Barranca de Cupatizio National Park.<ref name=mexdes/><ref name=inauguran/><ref name=gponce/>
In 2015, there were over one million pieces for sale, representing all of the major handcraft traditions.<ref name=inauguran/> These include textiles and traditional clothing, miniatures, jewelry, toys, furniture, lacquered gourds, chests, leather goods, iron, other metals, and the various types of ceramics produced, and those from stiff fibers such as wicker and palm fronds.<ref name=mexdes/> Most of the items for sale are of high quality and are of styles only found in Michoacan such as clay pots from Huancito with animal heads, needlework from Charan, pre Hispanic lacquerware (maque) from Uruapan, copper pieces from [[Santa Clara del Cobre]] and wooden masks from Pamatacuaro,<ref name=travis/> but there are some stands selling mostly tourist and cheap items.<ref name=mexdes/> For Palm Sunday, there are even more craftspeople, mostly Purépecha, on the atriums of the two main colonial churches, weaving palm fronds into intricate designs for churchgoers.<ref name=mexdes/>
==Related events== [[File:MuestraIndumentaria 2015 51.JPG|thumb|Purépecha children representing their community at the event in 2015]] Over its history, the tianguis proper has since been expanded with other cultural events such as music and dance performances, a parade of artisans, a food exhibition featuring the traditional cuisine of the Purépecha and more.<ref name=travis/><ref name=inauguran/>
The week is inaugurated with a parade of artisans and others in traditional dress, representing the four indigenous peoples found in the state, representing 45 communities and 25 Michoacan municipalities.<ref name=inauguran/> The parade also include artisans with examples of their wares such as those from Santa Clara del Cobre, Pamatacuaro and Paracho along with marching bands and mojigangas (large cartonería puppet figures) .<ref name=inauguran/><ref name=gponce/> The parade runs from the National Park to the center of the city along Culver City and Emilio Carranza streets, ending at the Casa de Cultura.<ref name=inauguran/> [[File:TianguiaPurhepechaFood33.JPG|thumb|left|Corundas (similar to tamales) steaming in a huge vat at the Plaza de la Ranita]] The Casa de Cultura host’s the state’s main handcraft competition, where winners are announced on Palm Sunday. In 2015, the competition awarded over a million pesos in prizes in 259 awards.<ref name=srangel/><ref name=mexdes/> On the same day there is the State Regional Costume Festival held at the Huatapera Museum, in which all four indigenous communities are represented, both in dress and traditions such as dance.<ref name=srangel/><ref name=mexdes/><ref name=visitmich/>
At the Plaza de la Ranita, there is a demonstration and sale of traditional Purépecha food, which includes [[pozole]], [[corunda]]s, atole, enchiladas, [[buñuelos]], uchepos (tamales of sweet corn) and fish dishes. The goal of this is to provide example of more traditional and less tourist foods. [[Atole]] includes the atolenuitede from San Miguel Pomocuaran, which is salty and spice with serrano chili peppers. Churipo is a beef soup, atole de pinole (with toasted corn), tamales de chapata, made with amaranth seed.<ref name=mexdes/> {{clear}}
==History== The event is located in Uruapan, which has been an important commercial center since the pre Hispanic period because it is centered among the major Purépecha regions (Lake, Purepech highlands, Cañada de los Once Pueblos and Ciènega de Chapala), as well as between the highlands and the “[[Tierra Caliente (Mexico)|Tierra Caliente]],” the lower elevations that extend to the coast.<ref name=visitmich/>
The area has been an important one for trade since the pre Hispanic period as it is centered among the major Purépecha regions (Lake, Purepech highlands, Cañada de los Once Pueblos and Ciènega de Chapala).<ref name=visitmich/><ref name=moreliainvita>{{cite web |title= Tianguis Artesanal Domingo de Ramos |publisher= Universidad La Salle |url= http://www.moreliainvita.com/paginas/contenido.php?id_evento=10394 |accessdate= April 4, 2015 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150412060406/http://www.moreliainvita.com/paginas/contenido.php?id_evento=10394 |archivedate= April 12, 2015 |df= }}</ref> The original tianguis was dedicated only to pottery. which lasted for two or three days on Melchor Ocampo Street onto Santiago Street and the Izazaga Plaza. Later, this area was remodeled to create the current Morelos Plaza. This posed a problem for the vendors until the current event was established in 1960.<ref name=moreliainvita/> {{commons category|Tianguis de Domingo de Ramos}}

Marie Haist (Mimi) |distributor =[[XLrator Media]] |released =May 2016 | runtime =76 minutes |country =United States |language =English }} '''''Queen Mimi''''' is a 2015 [[documentary]] film about the life of Marie Haist, an octogenarian homeless woman who lived in a Santa Monica laundromat for 18 years, directed by [[Yaniv Rokah]] and produced by [[Elliot V Kotek]].{{cite news|title=Thrillers, comedy and more coming to Vail Film Festival|url=http://www.vaildaily.com/news/15202674-113/thrillers-comedy-and-more-at-vail-film-fest|accessdate=26 March 2015|publisher=Vail Daily|date=27 February 2015}}{{cite news|title=Film About Montana's "Queen Mimi" Packs the House|url=http://www.westsidepeoplemag.com/2014/09/mimi-montana-ave-aero-theater/|accessdate=26 March 2015|publisher=West Side People Magazine|date=3 September 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Groves|first1=Don|title=Aussie makes docs with altruistic angle|url=http://if.com.au/2015/02/15/article/Aussie-makes-docs-with-altruistic-angle/JPAYRHHOHS.html|accessdate=26 March 2015|publisher=IF Magazine|date=16 February 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Burns|first1=Andrew|title=There's Something About Mimi|url=http://www.bigissue.com/mix/news/2399/there-s-something-about-mimi|accessdate=29 March 2015|publisher=The Big issue|date=23 May 2013}}[http://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-queen-mimi-20160513-story.html Los Angeles Times] == Release== The film was selected for the [[Sarasota Film Festival]].{{cite news|last1=Patterson|first1=Alan|title=2015 Sarasota Film Festival Announces Full Lineup|url=http://filmpulse.net/2015-sarasota-film-festival-announces-full-lineup/|accessdate=27 March 2015|publisher=Film Pulse|date=25 March 2015}} In May 2016 [[XLRator Media]] released the film worldwide.Anna Marie de la Fuente for Variety. December 3, 2015 [https://variety.com/2015/film/news/queen-mimi-xlrator-media-1201652989/ XLrator Media Picks Up Yaniv Rokah’s Documentary ‘Queen Mimi’] == Cast == *Mimi as herself *[[Zach Galifianakis]] as himself.{{cite news|title=‘Hangover’ Star Takes Laundry Pal From Homeless To The Red Carpet|url=http://losangeles.cbslocal.com/2013/05/21/hangover-star-takes-laundry-pal-from-homeless-to-the-red-carpet/|accessdate=26 March 2015|publisher=CBS Los Angeles|date=21 May 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Weisman|first1=Aly|title=Zach Galifianakis Bought A Homeless Woman An Apartment — And Took Her To 'The Hangover III' Premiere |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/zach-galifianakis-bought-homeless-woman-an-apartment-2013-5|accessdate=26 March 2015|publisher=Business Insider}} *Stan Fox as himself. ===Awards and nominations=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Award !Festival !Result |- |rowspan="1"|2015 |Best Documentary |[[Manhattan Film Festival]]{{cite news|last=McCollum|first=Brian|title=‘Queen Mimi’ Exclusive Clip: Watch 88-Year-Old Marie ‘Mimi’ Haist Dance and Sing Celine Dion’s ‘I’m Alive’|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2016/05/queen-mimi-exclusive-clip-watch-88-year-old-marie-mimi-haist-dance-and-sing-celine-dions-im-alive-290901|date=10 May 2016}} |{{Won}} |- |rowspan="1"|2015 |Spirit Award |[[Chagrin Documentary Film Festival]] |{{Won}} |- |rowspan="1"|2015 |Spirit Award |[[Hot Springs Documentary Film Festival]] |{{Won}} |- |rowspan="1"|2015 |Best Director Award |St Tropez International Film Festival |{{Won}} |} ==Soundtrack== ''Queen Mimi'' is a 2016 soundtrack album from the documentary containing a song by [[Grammy Awards]] nominee [[Deana Carter]] titled ''Celebrate Life''.[http://deana.com/how-a-weird-and-wonderful-friendship-between-a-generation-x-barista-and-a-homeless-nonagenarian-transformed-them-both-into-cinema-royalty/ Myra Chanin for Huffington Post. {{Infobox Website | name = Readgeek | logo = | logocaption = | screenshot = File:Screenshot_Readgeek_2017-04-05.png | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = homepage of Readgeek | url = {{URL|readgeek.com}} | commercial = | type = [[Book]] | registration = Free | language = [[English language|English]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[German language|German]], | content license = | owner = | author = Uwe Pilz | launch date = | alexa = | revenue = | current status = Active | footnotes = }} '''Readgeek''' is an online book [[recommendations engine]] and [[social cataloging]] service launched in December 2010. The website allows users to search for books matching their individual taste making use of several [[algorithm]]s. Taking ratings and [[metadata]] of prior read books into account, those algorithms help the site to learn about a users preferences. The service suggests books other users with similar tastes have enjoyed, rather than offering up books similar to the ones a user already ranked.<ref name=bu>{{Cite news| author= Hannah Nelson-Teutsch | title=With Readgeek, Online Book Recommendations Come In a Snap, and They're Good Ones to Boot | date=January 12, 2015 | url=https://www.bustle.com/articles/57839-with-readgeek-online-book-recommendations-come-in-a-snap-and-theyre-good-ones-to-boot | publisher =Bustle | accessdate = April 5, 2017}}</ref>
It is the first of its kind to give users a [[prediction]] of how much they will like almost any book.<ref name=fc>{{Cite news| author= Jessica Leber | title=A Site That Knows Your Favorite Books Before You Do | date=August 1, 2015 | url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3039862/a-site-that-knows-your-favorite-books-before-you-do | publisher =Fast Company | accessdate = April 5, 2017}}</ref> Users can also create reading lists, book discussions and [[Stream (computing)|follow the activities]] of other users. The company was invited in 2016 by the Dutch General Publishers Association to a worldwide innovation-competition for startups in the publishing industry.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Voigt|first1=Martin|title=Dutch Publishing Industry Seeks Startups Through the Renew the Book Competition|journal=Publishing Research Quarterly|date=20 December 2016|volume=33|issue=1|pages=10–13|doi=10.1007/s12109-016-9491-2}}</ref> The website's offices are in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Imprint of readgeek.com|url=https://www.readgeek.com/about/imprint|accessdate=5 April 2017}}</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Library 2.0]] is the concept behind Readgeek from a users perspective * [[Collaborative filtering]] and * [[Item-item collaborative filtering]] explain some background about the used algorithms<ref>{{cite web|title=How does Readgeek work?|url=https://www.readgeek.com/about/how_it_works|accessdate=7 April 2017}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}

{{for|the theatre in [[Bogotá]]|Teatro de Cristobal Colón}} {{Expand Spanish|Teatro Colón|date=March 2011}} {{Infobox building |name=Teatro Colón
Columbus Theatre |image=Frente del Teatro Colón.jpg |caption=
{{Location map|Argentina Buenos Aires City|width=|float=center |caption= |label=|position=right |lat_deg=34|lat_min=36|lat_sec=06|lat_dir=S |lon_deg=58|lon_min=23|lon_sec=07|lon_dir=W }}Location in Buenos Aires
|building_type=Arts complex |architectural_style=Eclecticism |structural_system=Concrete |location=[[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] |start_date =1889 |completion_date=1908 |height = 28 metres |diameter =58 metres |opened = |main_contractors= |architect=[[Francesco Tamburini]] |structural_engineer= |embedded = | url = {{Official website|http://www.teatrocolon.org.ar/en/}} }} [[File:Teatro Colón (2).jpg|thumb|Teatro Colón at night]] [[File:Vieja Recova.jpg|thumb|200px|1864 view of the original Teatro Colón (at left) and the old [[Plaza de Mayo]] colonnade, both long since demolished.]] [[File:Teatro colon 1881.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The first theatre (left), in front of [[Plaza de Mayo]] in 1881, photo by [[Alexander Witcomb]].]] [[File:Funcion de gala Teatro Colon 1935.png|thumb|150px|A 1935 gala premiere]] [[File:Teatro Colón, Buenos Aires.jpg|thumb|200px|Teatro Colón, 2010]] The '''''Teatro Colón''''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]]: ''Columbus Theatre'') is the main [[opera house]] in [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]]. It is considered one of the ten best opera houses in the world by National Geographic,[https://www.nationalgeographic.com/travel/top-10/opera-houses/ "Top 10: Opera Houses"] on travel.nationalgeographic.com. Retrieved 16 March 2018 and is acoustically considered to be amongst the five best concert venues in the world.Long, Marshall, [http://mlacoustics.com/PDF/Shoebox.pdf "What is So Special About Shoebox Halls? Envelopment, Envelopment, Envelopment"], ''Acoustics Today'', April 2009, pp.21–25. The other venues are Berlin's [[Konzerthaus Berlin| Konzerthaus]], Vienna's [[Musikverein]], the [[Concertgebouw]] in Amsterdam, and Boston's [[Symphony Hall, Boston|Symphony Hall]]. The present Colón replaced an original theatre which opened in 1857. Towards the end of the century it became clear that a new theatre was needed and, after a 20-year process, the present theatre opened on 25 May 1908, with [[Giuseppe Verdi]]'s ''[[Aïda]]''. The Teatro Colón was visited by the foremost singers and opera companies of the time, who would sometimes go on to other cities including [[Montevideo]], [[Rio de Janeiro]] and [[São Paulo]]. After this period of huge international success, the theatre's decline became clear and plans were made for massive renovations. After an initial start of works to restore the landmark in 2005, the theatre was closed for refurbishment from October 2006 to May 2010. It re-opened on 24 May 2010, with a programme for the 2010 season.[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/17/arts/17iht-turnbull.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=Teatro+Colon+Buenos+Aires&st=nyt Robert Turnbull, "An Operatic Drama Performed Mostly Offstage", ''[[New York Times]]'', 16 June 2010] Retrieved 10 Nov 2010 ==The first Teatro Colón== The first Teatro Colón was designed by [[Charles Pellegrini]], and proved to be a successful venue for over 30 years, with 2,500 seats with the inclusion of a separate gallery reserved only for people who were in mourning. The construction started in 1856 and completed in 1857. This was celebrated with an opening on April 27, 1857, with [[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s ''[[La traviata]]'', just four years after its Italian premiere. The production starred Sofia Vera Lorini as Violetta and [[Enrico Tamberlik]] as Alfredo. This theater was closed on September 13th 1888 to step aside for a new improved building, which was opened twenty years later on Libertad street, overlooking [[Plaza Lavalle]]. In that period of time, the 1890 crisis and its effects were the cause for the delay in the completion of this second theater. Before the construction of the current Teatro Colón, opera performances were given in several theatres, of which the first Teatro Colón and the [[Teatro Opera]] were the most important. The principal company that performed at the Teatro Opera moved to the Teatro Colón in 1908. However, major companies also performed at the Teatro Politeama and the [[Teatro Coliseo]] which opened in 1907. ==The present Teatro Colón== ===Characteristics=== The theatre is bounded by the wide [[9 de Julio Avenue]] (technically Cerrito Street), Libertad Street (the main entrance), Arturo Toscanini Street, and Tucumán Street.[http://www.teatrocolon.org.ar/English/history.htm History of the Colón Theatre (in English)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517070546/http://www.teatrocolon.org.ar/English/history.htm |date=2008-05-17 }} It is in the heart of the city on a site once occupied by [[Ferrocarril Oeste de Buenos Aires|Ferrocarril Oeste]]'s ''Plaza Parque'' station. The auditorium is horseshoe-shaped, has 2,487 seats (slightly more than the [[Royal Opera House]] in [[Covent Garden]], London), standing room for 1,000 and a stage which is 20 m wide, 15 m high and 20 m deep.[http://www.teatrocolon.org.ar/inicio.htm Official website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513191520/http://www.teatrocolon.org.ar/inicio.htm |date=2008-05-13 }} The low-rise building has 6 floors above ground and 3 below ground, 7 elevators with a facade of applied masonry. {{cite web |url=https://www.emporis.com/buildings/240774/teatro-colon-buenos-aires-argentina |title=Teatro Colón |author= |date= |website=Emporis |publisher= |access-date=June 13, 2017 |quote=}} It has a large central chandelier with 700 light bulbs. The original architect was the [[Italy|Italian]] Francesco Tamburini; after his death it was completed by the [[Belgium|Belgian]] architect Julio Dormal. The original auditorium "had eight boxes with metal grilles and a separate entrance, so that those in mourning could still attend performances, but remain dignifiedly sequestered from public view". {{cite web |url=https://www.architectural-review.com/rethink/buenos-aires-argentina-the-teatro-coln-opera-house-in-buenos-aires-is-finally-restored-to-its-luscious-former-glory/8604803.article |title=Buenos Aires, Argentina − The Teatro Colón opera house in Buenos Aires is finally restored to its luscious former glory |last=Slessor |first=Catherine |date=August 23, 2010 |website=The Architectural Review |publisher= |access-date=June 13, 2017 |quote=}} The Colon's [[acoustics]] are considered to be so good as to place it in the top five performance venues in the world. [[Luciano Pavarotti]] held a similar opinion.Luciano Pavarotti's reaction to the acoustics in Lynn, p.30: The theatre's "acoustics (have) the greatest defect: its acoustics are perfect! Imagine what this signifies for the singer: if one sings something bad, one notices immediately" ===Opening and subsequent history=== The present theatre, the second with that name, opened on 25 May 1908, after twenty years under construction,[http://www.haciendoelcolon.buenosaires.gob.ar/puesta-en-valor/historia/1 History of the Teatro Colón from haciendoelcolon.buenosaires.gob.ar (in Spanish)] Retrieved 9 Nov 2010 and was inaugurated with ''[[Aida]]'' by the Italian company directed by [[Luigi Mancinelli]] and tenor [[Amedeo Bassi]], soprano Lucia Crestani (as Aida). The second presentation was Thomas' ''[[Hamlet (opera)|Hamlet]]'' with the baritone [[Titta Ruffo]][http://www.operas-colon.com.ar/index1.htm Teatro Colon website (in Spanish)] During the inaugural season seventeen operas were performed with famous stars such as [[Titta Ruffo|Ruffo]], [[Feodor Chaliapin]] in [[Boito]]'s ''[[Mefistofele]]'', [[Antonio Paoli]] in [[Verdi]]'s ''[[Otello]]''. The cornerstone of the present Teatro Colón was laid in 1889 under the direction of architect [[Francesco Tamburini]] and his pupil, [[Vittorio Meano]], who designed a theatre in the Italian style on a scale and with amenities which matched those in Europe. However, delays followed due to financial difficulties, arguments regarding the location, the death of Tamburini in 1891, the murder of Meano in 1904 and the death of [[Angelo Ferrari]], an Italian businessman who was financing the new theatre. The building was finally completed in 1908 under the direction of the Belgian architect [[Julio Dormal]] who made some changes in the structure and left his mark in the French style of the decoration. The bas-reliefs and busts on the facade are the work of sculptor [[Luigi Trinchero]]. The theatre's opening on 25 May, the ''Día de la Patria'' in Argentina, featured a performance of Verdi's ''[[Aida]]'' and it quickly became a world-famous operatic venue rivaling [[La Scala]] and the [[Metropolitan Opera]] in attracting most of the world's best opera singers and conductors. The Teatro was bombed by anarchists in 1910; [[Georges Clemenceau]] was present in Argentina during the attack. The bomb landed in the middle of the orchestra. Clemenceau describes the attack as follows: "The horror can not be exaggerated. A senior official told me that he had never seen such puddles of blood. The wounded were carried off as best as possible, and the room was emptied by the cries of fury, and the material damage repaired during the day which followed, not a woman of society missed the representation of the morrow. It is a fine trait of character that particularly honors the female element of the Argentine nation. I am not quite sure that in Paris the hall would have been full in such cases." {{cite book |last=Clemenceau |first=Georges |date=1911 |title=Notes de voyage dans l'Amérique du sud : Argentine, Uruguay, Brésil |trans-title=Travel notes in South America: Argentina, Uruguay, Brazil |url=http://catalogue.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/cb319516000 |language=French |location=Paris |publisher=Hachette |isbn=}} Ballet stars performed at the Colón alongside Argentine dancers and classical instrumentalists. This included the prima ballerina, [[Lida Martinoli]].{{cite book|title=The Music Magazine/Musical Courier|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LuQKAQAAIAAJ|year=1953|page=xv}} When she retired from dancing, Martinoli began to choreograph. She died in [[Santa Fe, Argentina|Santa Fe]]. The tragic 1971 aviation death of two of the best known of these, [[Norma Fontenla]] and [[José Neglia]], was commemorated with a monument in neighbouring Lavalle Square. With excellent acoustics and modern stage areas, the theatre's interior design features a rich scarlet and gold decor. The [[cupola]] contains canvas painted in 1966 by the 20th-century artist [[Raúl Soldi]] during renovation work. ===Refurbishment, 2005 – 2010=== In recent years, given the political and economic circumstances of Argentina, the Teatro Colón has suffered considerably, but a period of slow recovery began. The theatre underwent massive phased remodelling of both interior and exterior, initially while the house was still open, but production activities ceased at the end of December 2006 to allow full refurbishment. Initially, "what had been planned as an 18-month, $25-million renovation with 500 workers, scheduled for a May 2008 reopening with ''Aida'', became a three-year $100-million extravaganza with 1,500 workers including 130 professional architects and engineers."Lynn, p. 29 In addition, an exterior open-air stage was planned for an opening in 2011. In all, {{convert|60000|sqm|sqft|0}} underwent updating, both inside and out. Some of the last performances immediately before closure of the theatre's building were ''[[Swan Lake]]'' on 30 September with the Ballet Estable del Teatro Colón and the [[Buenos Aires Philharmonic]] (''Orquesta Filarmónica de Buenos Aires'').[http://www.teatrocolon.org.ar/English/Programacion/Temporada2006/calendarios/septiembre06.htm Official Schedule for September 2006] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070717181220/http://www.teatrocolon.org.ar/English/Programacion/Temporada2006/calendarios/septiembre06.htm |date=2007-07-17 }} and, on 28 October, the opera ''[[Boris Godunov (opera)|Boris Godunov]]'' was given featuring Orquesta Estable del Teatro Colón and the house chorus.[http://www.teatrocolon.org.ar/English/Programacion/Temporada2006/calendarios/octubre06.htm Official Schedule for October 2006] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613073547/http://www.teatrocolon.org.ar/English/Programacion/Temporada2006/calendarios/octubre06.htm |date=2007-06-13 }} The theatre's final performance before its closure for refurbishment works in 2005 was a concert on 1 November starring folklore singer [[Mercedes Sosa]] in performance with the [[Argentine National Symphony Orchestra]], conducted by [[Pedro Ignacio Calderón]]. While it was originally planned to reopen in time for the centenary on 25 May 2008, delays prevented this, and the house was finally reopened with a gala concert and 3D animations on 24 May 2010, the eve of its own 102nd birthday and the [[Argentina Bicentennial]]. Tchaikovsky's ''[[Swan Lake]]'' and Act 2 of Puccini's ''[[La bohème]]'' were performed. A private concert to test the acoustics attended by employees, architects, and others involved in the renovation occurred on 6 May 2010.{{cite news | author = Daniel Fernández Quinti | title = Probaron que la acústica del Teatro Colón está intacta | quote = | publisher = ''Clarín'' (Buenos Aires) | date = 7 May 2010 | pages = | url = http://www.clarin.com/diario/2010/05/07/laciudad/h-02192467.htm | accessdate = 5 July 2010 (in Spanish) }} ==Image gallery==
File:Buenos Aires - San Nicolás - Teatro Colón.jpg|The Golden Room (''Salón Dorado'') File:Colon-interior-escenario-TM.jpg|Concert hall and stage File:La cúpula.jpg|Allegorical ceiling frescoes painted by [[Raúl Soldi]] File:Reapertura del Teatro Colón - Sala principal (4).jpg|Balconies File:Reapertura del Teatro Colón - Vista exterior del Teatro (3).jpg|Reopening celebrations File:Reapertura del Teatro Colón - Orquesta antes de La Boheme.jpg|Reopening Gala

{{About||the soundtrack|The Associate (soundtrack)|the novel by John Grisham|The Associate (novel)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = The Associate | image = Associate ver2.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Donald Petrie]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Frederic Golchan * [[Adam Leipzig]] * [[Patrick Markey]] }} | screenplay = Nick Thiel | based on = {{Plainlist| * {{based on|''El Socio''|Jenaro Prieto}} * {{based on|''L'Associé''|[[Jean-Claude Carrière]] (uncredited)
and [[René Gainville]] (uncredited)}} }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Whoopi Goldberg]] * [[Dianne Wiest]] * [[Tim Daly]] * [[Bebe Neuwirth]] * [[Eli Wallach]] }} | music = [[Christopher Tyng]] | cinematography = [[Alex Nepomniaschy]] | editing = Bonnie Koehler | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[Hollywood Pictures]] * [[Interscope Communications]] * [[PolyGram Filmed Entertainment]] }} | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Buena Vista Pictures]]
(North America)
PolyGram Filmed Entertainment
(international) | released = {{Film date|1996|10|25}} | runtime = 113 minutes{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/associate-1970-1 | title=''THE ASSOCIATE'' (PG) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=November 11, 1996 | accessdate=December 27, 2015}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = $12.8 million }} '''''The Associate''''' is a 1996 American [[comedy film]] directed by [[Donald Petrie]] and written by Nick Thiel, starring [[Whoopi Goldberg]], [[Dianne Wiest]], [[Eli Wallach]], [[Tim Daly]], and [[Bebe Neuwirth]], alongside [[Austin Pendleton]] and [[Lainie Kazan]]. ==Plot== Investment banker Laurel Ayres ([[Whoopi Goldberg]]) is a smart and single woman trying to make it up the Wall Street corporate ladder, until one day she finds out that she is passed over for a promotion because she is a woman. Unable to face the fact that her less intelligent male protege, Frank Peterson ([[Tim Daly]]), has now become her boss, she quits and tries to start up her own company only to find out that the male dominated world of Wall Street is not interested in taking an [[African American]] woman seriously, and thus is forced to create a fictional white man, Robert S. Cutty (inspired by a bottle of [[Cutty Sark]]) in order to be judged on her own merits. Ayres' financial wisdom is joined by the intelligent and computer-savvy secretary Sally Dugan ([[Dianne Wiest]]), who also was not properly recognized for her talents. Together they are able to become the most successful independent stockbrokers in the world while helping a struggling high-tech computer company stay afloat. However, the ruse eventually runs into problems, as Cutty is still getting credit for Ayres' great ideas, and competing firms and tabloid journalists are willing to do anything in order to bring the wealthy and elusive Cutty into the public and on their side. Thus Ayres is forced to get her best friend (who works at a nightclub as a female impersonator) to create an effective disguise in the mould of Marlon Brando to try to fool the naysayers; when that fails, she and Dugan decide to kill Cutty only to be charged with his murder. Frank uncovers the ruse and pretends that he is now the front man to world-famous Cutty. The film ends with Ayres donning the Cutty disguise one last time to attend a meeting of the exclusive gentlemen's club to accept Cutty's awards and unmasking herself in order to teach the male-dominated industry the evils of racial and sexual discrimination. Ayres is finally given credit for her work and creates a huge business empire with her friends at the helm. Frank attempts to land a job with the business, only to be laughed off. ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Whoopi Goldberg]] as Laurel Ayres / Mr. Robert S. Cutty * [[Dianne Wiest]] as Sally Dugan * [[Eli Wallach]] as Donald Fallon * [[Tim Daly]] as Frank Peterson * [[Bebe Neuwirth]] as Camille Scott * [[Austin Pendleton]] as Aesop Franklin * [[Lainie Kazan]] as Cindy Mason * George N. Martin as Walter Manchester * Kenny Kerr as Charlie * [[Lee Wilkof]] as Bissel * [[Željko Ivanek]] as [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]] Agent Tompkins * [[Colleen Camp|Colleen Camp Wilson]] as Detective Jones * [[Jerry Hardin]] as Harley Mason * [[Allison Janney]] as Sandy * [[Lawrence Gilliard, Jr.|Larry Gilliard, Jr.]] as Thomas * [[Vincent Laresca]] as José * [[Jonathan Freeman (actor)|Jonathan Freeman]] as Hockey game executive * [[John Rothman]] as Jogging track executive * [[Johnny Miller]] as himself * [[Sally Jessy Raphael]] as herself * [[Donald Trump]] as himself {{div col end}} ==Production== ===Development=== The film, a [[remake]] of [[René Gainville]]'s [[The Associate (1979 film)|1979 French film of the same name]], which, in turn, was based on [[Jenaro Prieto]]'s [[1928 in literature|1928 novel]] ''[[The Partner (Jenaro Prieto novel)|The Partner]]'' ===Soundtrack=== {{main article|The Associate (soundtrack)}} The [[soundtrack album]] for ''The Associate'' was released on October 15, 1996 by [[Motown|Motown Records]]. The soundtrack features [[Queen Latifah]], [[Sophie B. Hawkins]], American country singer [[Wynonna Judd]], Canadian-American recording artist [[Tamia Hill|Tamia]], [[CeCe Peniston]], [[Kate Pierson]] and [[Cindy Wilson]] (both of [[The B-52s]]), Jamaican reggae singer [[Patra (singer)|Patra]], and Swedish musician [[Louise Hoffsten]]. ==Release== ===Box office=== ''The Associate'' opened theatrically on October 25, 1996 in 1,781 venues and earned $4,261,304 in its opening weekend, ranking sixth in the domestic box office.{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=1996&wknd=43&p=.htm | title=Weekend Box Office Results for October 25-27, 1996 | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] | publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] | date=October 28, 1996 | accessdate=December 27, 2015}} At the end of its run, the film grossed $12,844,057 domestically.{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=associate.htm | title=The Associate (1996) | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] | publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] | accessdate=December 27, 2015}} ===Critical response=== The film received negative reviews from critics. On [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has a 28% rating based on 18 critics, with an average rating of 5.2/10.{{cite web | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1073315-associate/ | title=The Associate (1996) | work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher=[[Flixster]] | accessdate=December 27, 2015}} Peter Stack of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' finds Goldberg "very funny playing out her scheme, which inevitably backfires" and opines that "it's the peripheral characters that give the film its comic momentum." In contrast, [[Roger Ebert]] writing in the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'', gave this film two stars, calling it "an uninspired recycling of the ''[[Tootsie]]'' formula. Though the film "scores some good points against the male-dominated hierarchy of the business world," Ebert is ultimately unconvinced by the Cutty character. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0115580|The Associate}} * {{Mojo title|associate|The Associate}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|1073315-associate|The Associate}} {{Donald Petrie}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Associate, The}} [[Category:1996 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:1990s comedy films]] [[Category:American comedy films]] [[Category:Feminist films]] [[Category:American remakes of French films]] [[Category:Cross-dressing in American films]] [[Category:Films directed by Donald Petrie]] [[Category:Films set in New York City]] [[Category:Films shot in New York City]] [[Category:Films based on Chilean novels]] [[Category:Screenplays by Jean-Claude Carrière]] [[Category:Interscope Communications films]] [[Category:PolyGram Filmed Entertainment films]] [[Category:Hollywood Pictures films]] [[Category:African-American films]] [[Category:African-American comedy films]] [[Category:Mill Creek Entertainment]]
